I don't know if you still need this a month later, but here's what I got from it.  We want to find the scores that mark the middle 20% of the data (10% on each side of the middle line that separates the two halves of the distribution). 20% (20 out of 100) is the same as saying 0.2000 (0.2 out of 1). The whole area under the curve is 1 (or 100%). You only want the middle 0.2000 (or 0.1000 on each side of the central line). The area you do NOT want is the entire area (1) minus the area of interest (0.2000). Divide that by 2 so you can focus on the first half of the distribution. This way you obtain 0.4000. You could obtain the exact same result by considering half of the whole area (1/2 = 0.5000) and subtracting 0.1000 from it.  In order words, 0.4000 represents the first part of the area that you do NOT want to consider. When you find the z-score for 0.4000 and convert it to x, you'll find the lower limit of your interval (the lower score that marks the middle 20% of the data). Below that limit lies the 40% that you do NOT want to consider. For the upper limit, you can do the exact same thing on the other half of the area (in this case the z-score will be the opposite). Above that limit lies the 40% that you do NOT want to consider. In between   Hope this helps!  PS: I suggest you also have a look at her graph while going through this, I find it makes a lot more sense when you visualize things.

So, it's kind of like a 4 star system, except people rating or using the ratings to make their decisions don't necessarily all see the ratings equally.   The lower the rating, the more confusion. In a 0 to 5 scale, 1 star = 20%, while in a 1 to 5 scale 0 = to 0%. While in a 0 tp 5 scale, a 4.5 means 90%, while in a 1 to 5 scale 4.5 means 85%.
